subject: [devstack] block iPXE boot from HTTPS TempURLs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-23 16:33:25.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/lib/ironic'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/3edeb4c4f30bb9b6ab9b264020fba26ef1f5bed9', 'message': "[devstack] block iPXE boot from HTTPS TempURLs

While generally supported by iPXE, in DevStack we do not have any
facilities in place to boot iPXE from a HTTPS URL when the server is
using a custom certificate.
This is moslty concerning ability to boot iPXE directly from Swift's
TempURL when SSL is enabled on Swift in DevStack.

Just die with proper message when IRONIC_IPXE_USE_SWIFT and tls-proxy
are both enabled.

Change-Id: Ie0e01828f05b2706d310d8110e6e8dd8c4a03e4e
"}]
commit_message:
[devstack] block iPXE boot from HTTPS TempURLs

While generally supported by iPXE, in DevStack we do not have any
facilities in place to boot iPXE from a HTTPS URL when the server is
using a custom certificate.
This is moslty concerning ability to boot iPXE directly from Swift's
TempURL when SSL is enabled on Swift in DevStack.

Just die with proper message when IRONIC_IPXE_USE_SWIFT and tls-proxy
are both enabled.

Change-Id: Ie0e01828f05b2706d310d8110e6e8dd8c4a03e4e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/03/547503/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(pas-ha) find a way to (cross-)sign the custom CA bundle used by tls-proxy # with default iPXE cert - for reference see http://ipxe.org/crypto if [ $IRONIC_IPXE_USE_SWIFT == 'True' && is_service_enabled tls-proxy ]; then die $LINENO "Ironic in DevStack does not yet support booting iPXE from HTTPS URLs" fi

subject: Move resource class fields
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-01 17:38:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c6c5d304e77a592e0ab8ad35e79984a40e31df11', 'message': 'WIP: Move resource provider objects into placement hierarchy

This is so we don't have all the other objects imported into the
the placement process, which happens by virtue of being in the
nova.objects package. It also eases the eventual extraction of
placement.

In the process make some adjustments to minimize the amount of
"nova" in the objects that placement uses:

* Make the resource provider objects inherit from oslo_versionedobjects,
  not nova objects.
* Move the ResourceClass field to its own package, and move that package
  to the top of the nova hierarchy since it is used by both nova tooling
  and placement tooling but we don't want the placement version to have
  to incorporate the nova code.

This latter change is the source of most of the changes, as
standard ResourceClass fields are used all over the place and we need
to distinguish between other fields and the resource class fields.
I considered providing a sort of proxy class, but being explicit seemed
better.

Change-Id: Iea182341f9419cb514a044f76864d6bec60a3683

commit_message:
Move resource class fields

Move the ResourceClass field to its own package, and move that package
to the top of the nova hierarchy since it is used by both nova tooling
and placement tooling but we don't want the placement version to have to
incorporate the nova code. Eventually we'd like to see an
os-resource-classes library, similar to os-traits, which will serve this
functionality. This is a step in that direction.

Changes in this patch are quite widespread, but are mostly only changes
of imports.

Change-Id: Iea182341f9419cb514a044f76864d6bec60a3683

commit_message:
kernel: make ExtraKernelModules and ExtraSysctlSettings role-specific

Allow to configure extra Kernel modules and extra sysctl settings per role
and not only global to the whole deployment.
The two parameters that can be role-specific are ExtraKernelModules and
ExtraSysctlSettings.

commit_message:
Don't double load config

This isn't necessary and will likely have some bad side effects
because re-calling the conf object clears all previously registered
opts, which defeats the purpose of the second call.

Change-Id: I59bd78e85b3d55aea23b46809f4de678d394f66d
Related-Bug: 1751815

commit_message:
Adding the class and mac approach as dpdk-devargs in mellanox ConnectX-3

Some NICs (i.e. Mellanox ConnectX-3) have only one PCI address
associated with multiple ports. Using a PCI address as dpdk-devargs
in OvsDpdkPort won't work. Instead, class and mac approach is used
dpdk-devargs="class=eth,mac=<MAC>"
see this http://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/howto/dpdk/

Closes-Bug: #1754256
Change-Id: I29de6e82a0897ee46953a1e6a966e9c5790068c9
(cherry picked from commit aeaa6fe62b39a00f3b075a94c076f267f0c70af0)

commit_message:
Adding a workaround for enabling steering in ConnectX-3 devices

This file will add this configuration
"options mlx4_core log_num_mgm_entry_size=-1" to
/etc/modprobe.d/mlx4.conf file in order to enable steering in
ConnectX-3 devices and then will rebuild the initramfs at the first
boot stage

Closes-Bug: #1754260
Change-Id: Ia64e62e7fdb70e19be7b0a5cee163bd03c6de65d
(cherry picked from commit bbc8e0ac3e37752b4f114811878cabd544746923)

commit_message:
undercloud: create EnableValidations

If validations are enabled, set EnableValidations to true.
It'll allow containerized undercloud to run workbooks usually executed
by instack-undercloud, in
THT/extraconfig/post_deploy/undercloud_post.sh.

Change-Id: I10abed7f1514e9d72d5ebac0c85bad11cdf3210f

retrieving the content when the console output is requested.

The issue is that the log file used by os-win never gets flushed
(unless closed). For this reason, we're returning incomplete output.

This change ensures that we're flushing the log file before attempting

Closes-Bug: #1741494

Change-Id: Ic558b16b317e0b1478cc259327d1336f7589afe3

commit_message:
Flush console log file before retrieving content

Hyper-V exposes instance serial console ports through named pipes.
We're consuming those named pipes, logging the output to a file,
retrieving the content when the console output is requested.

The issue is that the log file used by os-win never gets flushed
(unless closed). For this reason, we're returning incomplete output.

This change ensures that we're flushing the log file before attempting
to read its content.

Closes-Bug: #1741494

Change-Id: Ic558b16b317e0b1478cc259327d1336f7589afe3
Depends-On: I4b5eb7579ac0c92e9c3630539b0c4d76f5b98c6d
(cherry picked from commit eb2c7b20a3e1328c1f3f5569bb5956a8ec230e8b)

commit_message:
Use stable-pike build of horizon for stable/pike

This patch changes tox to use the appropriate stable
build of Horizon.

We are currently always pulling the very latest version
of Horizon for all our gates. This is usually fine for the 
first few months, but over time it's likely that Horizon 
introduces changes that will break the designate-dashboard tests
and block the gate.

Change-Id: I3cecd9e1adce7ef0748f181050ed5d7cbe0da317
Closes-Bug: #1754269

commit_message:
Remove @expression from tags

This change makes tags a property of Project instead of a hybrid_property
since we will always have a Project contain some list of tags.

Co-Authored-By: Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add custom action to add dns entries via novajoin

When TLS is setup using novajoin, the IdM server should be
used for DNS.  This patch provides custom actions/workflow to
create the required entries through a call to novajoin.

This patch partially resolves BZ 1534070.

Change-Id: I6bd2dd42e57cf84dadce6476317d3a118bf14110
Depends-On: Icfd51fa665f32ff381be9d6db728d4b0fd00dd3e

commit_message:
WIP: Add DNS data to IdM

When TLS is set up using novajoin and IdM, the IdM server should
be used for DNS.  This patch provides DNS data to novajoin so that
it can add it to IdM in two ways.
* by adding VipDnsData to the instance metadata to be processed on
  server instantiation.
* by calling a custom action to add entries when the deployment
  is complete

Change-Id: Ia8a282a2f8c2a6941c4e8735c797b01fd3790a63
Depends-On: I6bd2dd42e57cf84dadce6476317d3a118bf14110

commit_message:
[CVE-2018-1000115] memcached: restrict to TCP & localhost

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2018-1000115

Restrict Memcached to only work on TCP and localhost.
The restriction is made at the application and firewall levels.
It will prevent DDoS amplification attacks using memcached.

Change-Id: I8072cc842291d133fde9fdfe9e8ad432623a8ef2
Related-Bug: #1754607

commit_message:
Add ansible-lint rule for apt_repository

This rule is designed to prevent the Ansible module `apt_repository`
from being used to update the APT cache. There is a bug [1] in
`apt_repository` that prevents cache updates from being performed
whenever the module is retried. If the cache update fails at the first
attempt, it is skipped on the subsequent attempt of the task causing the
task to always complete successfully. Until this bug is addressed this
rule should prevent it from being introduced into OpenStack-Ansible.

Partial-bug: 1750656

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/36605

Change-Id: If440ce129c31fb4e62a8e0ac5094195f4d4d7167
(cherry picked from commit 67bfc907030d7f0ce6fbb63f0608aa021f0b5400)

" "Disable cache updates by setting `update_cache: no` and use a " "separate apt task to update the APT cache. This bug is tracked by " "https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/36605." ) tags = ["bug"] def matchtask(self, file, task): module = task["action"]["__ansible_module__"] update_cache_enabled = task["action"].get("update_cache", True) return module == "apt_repository" and update_cache_enabled

subject: Add deploy_status to plan-environment

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-07 15:29:54.000000000', 'files': ['plan-environment.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/a5c7cbf5d838c3fb97180f48ea66451f288c5640', 'message': "Add deploy_status to plan-environment

Now that we support deploying via --config-download, it's no longer
possible for e.g the UI to monitor the status of the plan deployment
via the heat stack status, so add a status key to the plan-environment.

This can be used to check the status of the plan deployment after the
plan create/update/delete has finished (e.g there's no status on the
zaqar queue to consume).

The mistral workflows that manage the plan lifecycle will update the
value as appropriate, e.g:

CREATED - plan validated and created in swift
DEPLOYING - deployment is in-progress (either heat or configuration)
ERROR - deployment failed with some error
DELETED - plan still exists but the deployment has been deleted

We could consider splitting DEPLOYING perhaps to differentiate
the heat stack (PROVISIONING?) phase with the ansible/config-download
phase (CONFIGURING?)

Change-Id: I9a08bcd45be082b0050cb77ca9587520da5f8280
"}]
commit_message:
Add deploy_status to plan-environment

Now that we support deploying via --config-download, it's no longer
possible for e.g the UI to monitor the status of the plan deployment
via the heat stack status, so add a status key to the plan-environment.

This can be used to check the status of the plan deployment after the
plan create/update/delete has finished (e.g there's no status on the
zaqar queue to consume).

The mistral workflows that manage the plan lifecycle will update the
value as appropriate, e.g:

CREATED - plan validated and created in swift
DEPLOYING - deployment is in-progress (either heat or configuration)
ERROR - deployment failed with some error
DELETED - plan still exists but the deployment has been deleted

We could consider splitting DEPLOYING perhaps to differentiate
the heat stack (PROVISIONING?) phase with the ansible/config-download
phase (CONFIGURING?)

Change-Id: I9a08bcd45be082b0050cb77ca9587520da5f8280

commit_message:
Mock retry in test_remove_block_dev

test_remove_block_dev was a very long running test. It was not mocking
retrying.retry and the retries would continue until the retry timeout
was hit. This adds test_remove_block_dev_timeout which mocks retry
while verifying the RetryError device deletion failure case to reduce
the test runtime.

Change-Id: I8cf674cb48d672bde3ce44660bc619aa4c914e62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/21/548721/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support disabling a cell

It would be useful to have a mechanism by which we could totally stop
scheduling to a particular cell or a group of cells by supporting the
concept of disabling cells. Given that we do not have any existing
means to disable a cell, this spec proposes a simple solution to
support this new feature in nova.

Change-Id: I22bfe4dbe8325e57cef9959c38adda94fef28d73
Implements: blueprint cell-disable
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/84/546684/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support disabling a cell ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cell-disable It would be useful to have a mechanism by which we could totally stop scheduling to a particular cell or a group of cells by supporting the concept of disabling cells. Given that we do not have any existing means to disable a cell, this spec proposes a simple solution to support this new feature in nova. Problem description =================== Currently we have a number of ways to pre-select cells into which we want the vms to be scheduled into, like using host aggregates or scheduler filters. These mechanisms however are white listing and selecting suitable hosts by which we are indirectly able to pre-select a cell. So although we have ways to remove undesired hosts from being selected for scheduling, large deployments may not always want to engage on a host-level. If they want to just stop scheduling to a set of cells, presently they would some how have to deal with ensuring none of the hosts in those cells are filtered out by the scheduler since there is no way to simply black list those set of cells. So the problem that this spec is trying to address is the fact that there is no elegant way to block scheduling to a group of cells. Use Cases --------- As an operator, I wish to disable a group of cells (like during failures or interventions when new instances should not be spawned) so as to stop scheduling to them without having to deal with the individual compute nodes (micromanagement). Proposed change =============== This spec aims to make a change in the ``nova_api.cell_mappings`` table schema and add a new field to the ``CellMapping`` object through which the host_manager of the scheduler will become aware of the cells which are disabled and there by not query for those compute nodes and services which belong to the disabled cells while getting the host states of the hosts returned by placement to the scheduler. A detailed procedure of how this is aimed to be implemented is explained below: #. Add a new column ``disabled`` to the nova_api.cell_mappings table which can be set to either 1 or 0 for each record. Setting it to 1 means that cell is disabled; and so by default this value will be set to 0. #. Add a new field ``disabled`` to the CellMapping object which will represent the value of the newly added column in the cell_mappings table. #. Add a query method to CellMappingList object, to query for only the enabled cells. #. Presently the scheduler calls the host_manager to get_host_states_by_uuids and the host_manager queries for the compute_nodes and services in the cells by calling _get_computes_for_cells from get_host_states_by_uuids function. While loading the cells in the get_host_states_by_uuids function, the disabled cells will be filtered out and only the enabled cells will be passed to the _get_computes_for_cells function by using the new query added to CellMappingList. Hence only the states of hosts in the enabled cells will be passed back to the filter scheduler so that no scheduling happens to the disabled cells. #. If the ``spec_obj.requested_destination.cell`` is a disabled cell, the scheduling will fail with an appropriate log error message. Since we have the nova-manage utility for the operators, the nova-manaage command to update the fields in the cell_mappings table, can be reused in the following manner, thus allowing the user to enable/disable a cell. * Add new flags to ``nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell`` command - * ``nova-manage cell_v2 --update_cell --cell_uuid <cell_uuid> [--disable]`` which will disable an enabled cell, meaning set the ``diasbled`` field of this cell's cell_mapping record in the api DB to 1. * ``nova-manage cell_v2 --update_cell --cell_uuid <cell_uuid> [--enable]`` which will enable a disabled cell, meaning set the ``disabled`` field of this cell_mapping record back to 0. The scope of this spec is limited to considering the scenario of using a filter scheduler since that is the maintained scheduler. Alternatives ------------ #. This could also be implemented as a post-placement filter enabled through a config boolean in the scheduler to filter out disabled cells, but since this would anyways still need a new field in cell_mappings, it would be more integrated if this is implemented through a simple change in query in the host_manager. #. Another alternative would be loop through all the compute services in that cell and enable/disable them, but this may not be ideal in cases of cells having large number of computes. Data model impact ----------------- A nova_api DB schema change will be required for adding the ``disabled`` column of type tinyint to the ``nova_api.cell_mappings`` table. An api_migration will be required. This column will be set to 0 by default. At the same time, the ``CellMapping`` object will need to gain a new field called ``disabled``. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Users will gain two new options to the existing ``nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell`` command called ``disable`` and ``enable``. The documentation will be updated to benefit the users. Performance Impact ------------------ There will not be any major impact on performance. Instead of the scheduler querying for all the cells to get the host states it will query for only enabled cells. Other deployer impact --------------------- There will not be any impact on the deployer operations since by default all the cells will be enabled and scheduling will work normally. Supporting cell disable will only make it more agile since the deployer can now block scheduling to a group of cells, rather than involving in micromanagement of services, meaning individually tend to each service in those cells by filtering them out or disabling each compute service in that cell. Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- Since there will be a change in the api DB schema, the ``nova-manage api_db sync`` command will have to be run to update the cell_mappings table. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <tssurya> Other contributors: <belmoreira> Work Items ---------- #. Add a new column ``disabled`` to nova_api.cell_mappings table. #. Add a new field ``disabled`` to CellMapping object. #. Add a query method to CellMappingList to obtained all the cell mapping records of enabled cells. #. Change the method of querying for the host states in the host_manager to only query in the enabled cells. #. Add the new flags to the nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell command. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= #. Unit and functional tests for verifying the working of the disabling mechanism Documentation Impact ==================== The nova-manage documentation for the users would be updated by documenting the new flags for the ``nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell`` command in nova-manage.rst file. References ========== None. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Rocky - Introduced

conf: Remove 'nova.crypto' opts

These are no longer used since [1] and can be immediately removed
without a deprecation cycle.

[1] Ie1dadc6bf935f777e0cd0c54a0a21b79545714c5

commit_message:
use defusedxml to avoid XML attack

According to https://docs.openstack.org/bandit/latest/api/bandit.blacklists.html

Using various XML methods to parse untrusted XML data is known to be vulnerable
to XML attacks. Methods should be replaced with their defusedxml equivalents.

Change-Id: Icdd807c8fd47ce0df3e292eef910e6e6e7610686
Partial-Bug: #1732155

deleted_lines: from lxml import etree xml_tree = etree.fromstring(data)

commit_message:
crypto: Remove unused functions

These top-level functions were not called from anywhere but tests.

- fetch_ca
- ensure_ca_filesystem
- fetch_crl
- decrypt_text
- revoke_certs_by_user
- revoke_certs_by_project
- revoke_certs_by_user_and_project
- generate_x509_cert
- generate_vpn_files

These other functions are used by the above and are no longer used
anywhere.

- ca_folder
- ca_path
- key_path
- crl_path
- revoke_cert
- _project_cert_subject
- _user_cert_subject
- _ensure_project_folder
- sign_csr
- _sign_csr

Tests for these are removed as are a number of scripts found in
'nova/CA', which were only used by the aforementioned functions.

Change-Id: Ie1dadc6bf935f777e0cd0c54a0a21b79545714c5

subject: Allow for merging traits and aggregates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-12 19:20:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/776cb1debdf69ae09f35e8056ef2fb09da3abd1a', 'message': 'Allow for merging traits

Per discussions at the PTG [1] as concluded in IRC [2][3],
update_provider_tree needs to set and unset only the traits it "owns",
rather than replacing a provider's traits wholesale.  To facilitate
this, we're adding a ProviderTree.merge_traits method.

[1] Awkwardly pasted, since no etherpad permalink: http://paste.openstack.org/raw/698758/
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-03-12-14.00.log.html#l-217

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-03-12 20:00:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/7cb6328bf268ead5ed4bb301696b7f210c7632ba', 'message': 'Allow for merging traits and aggregates

Per discussions at the PTG [1] as concluded in IRC [2][3][4],
update_provider_tree needs to set and unset only the traits and

To facilitate this, we're adding ProviderTree methods add_traits,
remove_traits, add_aggregates, and remove_aggregates.

commit_message:
Allow for merging traits and aggregates

Per discussions at the PTG [1] as concluded in IRC [2][3][4],
update_provider_tree needs to set and unset only the traits and
aggregate associations it "owns", rather than replacing them wholesale.
To facilitate this, we're adding ProviderTree methods add_traits,
remove_traits, add_aggregates, and remove_aggregates.

[1] Awkwardly pasted, since no etherpad permalink: http://paste.openstack.org/raw/698758/
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-03-12-14.00.log.html#l-217
[3] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2018-03-12.log.html#t2018-03-12T16:08:09
[4] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2018-03-12.log.html#t2018-03-12T18:29:56

Change-Id: I0a1ffa4e3849ea5ed9f5252c38e5cf646eebfd62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/22/552122/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: Traits are special. Rather than overwriting the entire set of traits for a provider, this method needs to use `ProviderTree.merge_traits`_ to assert or deassert all and only the traits "owned" by the virt driver. This allows outside agents (like operators) control over other traits. * ``merge_traits``: Set or unset virt-owned traits for a provider (see `ProviderTree.merge_traits`_).ProviderTree.merge_traits ------------------------- Since outside agents (e.g. operators) need to be able to set and unset traits which are outside of the purview of the virt driver, `ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree`_ needs to be able to add and remove traits explicitly, rather than simply overwriting the entire set of traits for a given provider. This ProviderTree method accepts three arguments: * ``name_or_uuid``: Either the name or the UUID of the resource provider whose traits are to be merged. * ``traits_add``: A set of string names of traits to ensure are set. * ``traits_rem``: A set of string names of traits to ensure are unset. When the method completes, the following are guaranteed:: ProviderTree.data(name_or_uuid).traits & traits_add == traits_add ProviderTree.data(name_or_uuid).traits & traits_rem == {} Any traits outside of ``traits_add | traits_rem`` are untouched. ``ValueError`` is raised if ``traits_add & traits_rem != {}``.
deleted_lines: * ``update_traits``: Set the traits for a provider.

commit_message:
[CVE-2018-1000115] memcached: restrict to TCP & localhost

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2018-1000115

Restrict Memcached to only work on TCP and localhost.
The restriction is made at the application and firewall levels.
It will prevent DDoS amplification attacks using memcached.

Change-Id: I8072cc842291d133fde9fdfe9e8ad432623a8ef2
Related-Bug: #1754607
(cherry picked from commit 74fc85c507fc298828797c51255cee059a9684fc)

commit_message:
Updating time for functional tests

Currenlty, some gates is being failed with logs like this

"""
b'Response: {"description": "Provided object does not match schema
\'Secret\': \'expiration\' is before current time.
Invalid property: \'expiration\'", "title": "Bad Request", "code": 400}'
"""

So it is necessary to update the time to create secrets successfully.

Change-Id: I59707cdf21f6843dbd7db30978e21cff72756e67

commit_message:
Fix for difference in tzinfo.tzname value between py27 and py35

The tzinfo.tzname value differs between py27 and py35.
For example, 'UTC' for py27, 'UTC+00:00' for py35.
Therefore, it is necessary to change the way to get the date string.

Change-Id: Iae5539e0aec0fab0a08640f7f6600a1d91b241e5
Closes-Bug: #1753644

commit_message:
base: use ERP:kolla:queens repo for Debian

At Linaro we try to keep repositories with extra packages as separate as
it is possible. ERP:kolla is used for 'master' builds and we had
'ERP:kolla:pike' in past.

So I created 'ERP:kolla:queens' repo for stable/queens builds.

Change-Id: I6de4e1d1bf214f364b907ab85a0d0eeb233b4952

commit_message:
Update for upcoming openstacksdk changes to masakari-monitors

In the next openstacksdk release, Profile is going away as are entrypoints
plugins. This handles fixing most of that in a way that should work with
both old and new.

Note: This code has been tested with a version other than
openstacksdk-0.10.0.

Change-Id: Ic6390b0a479529600d246e3ced9e7278f08054df

commit_message:
Use node traits during upgrade

Now that the queens branch has support for node traits in the devstack
plugin [1], we can apply node traits when testing upgrades from queens
or later.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/551938

Change-Id: I99b9487d849ecd5241657d6ca91c2e9f9f7dfcf8
Related-Bug: #1722194
Related-Bug: #1750027

commit_message:
Remove default value for Cinder Auth Strategy

Cinder supports both noauth and keystone auth mode. So now we can
configure this value via local.conf:

[[post-config|$CINDER_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
auth_strategy = noauth

Change-Id: I1e434362117ab30dae71a8f3a80bc139e78f51bc

commit_message:
Make test allowed_pattern type same as the hot example and fix the gate

This reverts commit 51818f07d12d7eb776dc480585c2df23fbaf812a and forward
ports the testing change from stable pike:

In murano allowed_pattern set as:
allowed_pattern: [A-Za-z0-9]
But in hot example is set as:
allowed_pattern: '[a-zA-Z0-9]*'

So change the test template allowed_pattern.

Change-Id: I89ac4ef9de5eb0a5176c9df2ce1f289ca0d2cc65
(cherry picked from commit a682d5ee923912f9bdff49f9c5dc1847a40e7c33)

commit_message:
Allow to configure max vlans for trunk port tests

In NFV baremetal deployments, the number of vlans available for trunk
ports may be constrained. This patch allows to configure
max_networks_per_project to accommodate for those environments.

Change-Id: Ie0f04649313aed41498cf60f7de0eb44cee17b1c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/40/529040/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: allowed_vlans = range(3, 7) # support for providers network if len(CONF.neutron_plugin_options.provider_vlans) > 0: allowed_vlans = CONF.neutron_plugin_options.provider_vlans for seg_id in allowed_vlans]

Change-Id: I90dd28b8c5d981e6028af353e34645712ef09b0b

commit_message:
Remove customizable for plugins_pip_packages

The pip packages are normally already configurable with the
<image_name>_pip_packages variable. It doesn't make much sense to make
the list of packages installed with the plugins mechanism configurable
via the <image_name>_plugins_pip_packages variable too.

And even if we wanted to, the parameter to the `customizable()`
function should be 'plugins_pip_packages' and not 'pip_packages'.

This commit removes the customizable bits from the plugins install
macro, at least until we get a good use case for it.

Change-Id: I90dd28b8c5d981e6028af353e34645712ef09b0b

subject: Support configuration of Kafka package
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-08 17:28:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/a162f69134430a2f3f87fca0248c91ac9bdab968', 'message': 'Suport configuration of Kafka package

This change makes it easier to configure the Kafka package. This
is useful, for example, when installing Monasca which currently
requires an older version of Kafka than that installed here.

The change also verifies the sha512sum of the package. The
sha512sum was taken from here:

https://www.apache.org/dist/kafka/1.0.0/kafka_2.12-1.0.0.tgz.sha512

commit_message:
Support configuration of Kafka package

This change makes it easier to configure the Kafka package. This
is useful, for example, when installing Monasca which currently
requires an older version of Kafka than that installed here.

The change also fixes an issue with circular symlinks, updates
kafka and verifies the sha512sum of the package. The sha512sum
was taken from here:

https://www.apache.org/dist/kafka/1.0.1/kafka_2.12-1.0.1.tgz.sha512

Change-Id: I79a5a32ee8e5edd915fa88fbc00d0d4ac08b8ebd
Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles

commit_message:
trivial: Remove cruft from 'conf.py'

This serves as a reference guide of sorts. No need to keep all the noise
around.

Change-Id: Id9a636a4e4d7586ad395e2a2eb00b3bc08c61fa2

commit_message:
Move code out of '__init__'

We shouldn't be placing stuff here. Let's split it out, in preparation
for some other functionality.

Imports are retained for older applications.

Change-Id: I79bd88d0dc10d485022fa36fe869b9b73ade3e82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstackdocstheme refs/changes/67/552067/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2018 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os.path def get_pkg_path(): return os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__)) def get_html_theme_path(): """Return the directory containing HTML theme for local builds.""" return os.path.join(get_pkg_path(), 'theme') def get_pdf_theme_path(): """Return the directory containing PDF theme for local builds.""" args = ['theme', 'openstackdocs_pdf', 'pdftheme'] return os.path.join(get_pkg_path(), *args) def get_openstack_logo_path(): """Return the directory containing openstack logo for local builds.""" args = ['theme', 'openstackdocs_pdf', 'openstack-logo-full.png'] return os.path.join(get_pkg_path(), *args)

Mark some functions as private

There's no reason to expose these publicly. Don't do it.

added_lines: _series = Nonedef _get_series_name(): global _series if _series is None: _series = 'latest' else: _series = branch.rpartition('/')[-1] return _series def _setup_link_roles(app): series = _get_series_name()def _builder_inited(app): theme_dir = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'theme') logger.info('Using openstackdocstheme Sphinx theme from %s' % theme_dir) _setup_link_roles(app) app.connect('builder-inited', _builder_inited)

commit_message:
ffu: Introduce prep workarounds for FFU

We make sure is_bootstrap_node is always set and we reset hiera
hierarchy on first run.

Resolves: rhbz#1535406
Clodes-Bug: #1743740
Change-Id: Ib5cc32b798118c85bf09beab097be2f6eaeb405f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/97/541397/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {%- for role in roles %} {%- set server_resource_name = role.deprecated_server_resource_name|default(role.name) -%} - shell: | #!/bin/bash if [ ! -f /root/.ffu_workaround ]; then touch /root/.ffu_workaround os-apply-config -m /var/lib/os-collect-config/{{server_resource_name}}Deployment.json systemctl stop os-collect-config rm -r /var/lib/os-collect-config/* rm -f /usr/libexec/os-refresh-config/configure.d/40-hiera-datafiles rm -f /usr/libexec/os-apply-config/templates/etc/puppet/hiera.yaml rm -f /usr/libexec/os-refresh-config/configure.d/10-hiera-disable fi when: role_name == '{{role.name}}' name: Run Fast Forward Upgrade Prep Workarounds for {{role.name}} {%- endfor %}

subject: Move gnocchi api in wsgi back to python2
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-11 09:19:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-gnocchi/commit/13f12f86c5a54b60882ca96be4abaafa97b0928a', 'message': 'Move gnocchi api in wsgi back to python2

Canonical are packaging gnocchi-api package with apache
and python3 by default. We cannot test it in CI since
we cannot run py2 and py3 on the same node with apache wsgi.

Canonical helped us by packaging python2 support back into
python-gnocchi package so we change our wsgi usage to use
this package and set the new wsgi script path.

We still want users to be able to install only gnocchi-api
since they might not run apache wsgi even though its installed by
default.

Adds installation of rados and redis packages for python3
when needed, this is because all gnocchi components will
still be running in py3, also CLI such as gnocchi-upgrade
but the gnocchi-api is in wsgi using py2. Because of that
we still need to install the py2 packages.

Enables acceptance testing for Debian based operating systems.

Change-Id: I070f88dd40ca4129cbd3abf5b4f5ecb511b2895e

commit_message:
Move gnocchi api in wsgi back to python2

Canonical are packaging gnocchi-api package with apache
and python3 by default. We cannot test it in CI since
we cannot run py2 and py3 on the same node with apache wsgi.

Canonical helped us by packaging python2 support back into
python-gnocchi package so we change our wsgi usage to use
this package and set the new wsgi script path.

We still want users to be able to install only gnocchi-api
since they might not run apache wsgi even though its installed by
default.

Adds installation of rados and redis packages for python3
when needed, this is because all gnocchi components will
still be running in py3, also CLI such as gnocchi-upgrade
but the gnocchi-api is in wsgi using py2. Because of that
we still need to install the py2 packages.

Enables acceptance testing for Debian based operating systems.

Change-Id: I070f88dd40ca4129cbd3abf5b4f5ecb511b2895e
(cherry picked from commit 56794f300acaf0c2dd46a0bac3830f7c90120670)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-gnocchi refs/changes/54/551754/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it { is_expected.not_to contain_package('python3-rados') } shared_examples 'gnocchi storage ceph ubuntu' do context 'with manage_rados set to true installs python3-rados on Ubuntu' do before do params.merge!({ :manage_cradox => false, :manage_rados => true, }) end it { is_expected.to contain_package('python3-rados').with(:ensure => 'present') } end end if facts[:operatingsystem] == 'Ubuntu' then it_behaves_like 'gnocchi storage ceph ubuntu' end

commit_message:
Define devstack services without the test-matrix

Emit a disable_all_services and define which service we run in
the job directly. This drops the dependency from the test matrix,
from devstack default list of services and it makes it easier for
jobs to add/remove services based on the list in the base job.

Change-Id: Ib1debefd541b933dbfc54d484c263cc0ed60423d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/65/546765/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ignore base set of services setup by test-matrix. # Ignore any default set by devstack. Emit a "disable_all_services". base: false # Core services enabled for this branch. # This list replaces the test-matrix. # Shared services dstat: true etcd3: true mysql: true peakmem_tracker: true rabbit: true tls-proxy: true # Keystone services key: true # Glance services g-api: true g-reg: true # Nova services n-api: true n-api-meta: true n-cauth: true n-cond: true n-cpu: true n-novnc: true n-obj: true n-sch: true placement-api: true # Neutron services q-agt: true q-dhcp: true q-l3: true q-meta: true q-metering: true q-svc: true # Swift services s-account: true s-container: true s-object: true s-proxy: true # Cinder services c-api: true c-bak: true c-sch: true c-vol: true cinder: true # Services we don't need. # This section is not really needed, it's for readability. # Test matrix emits ceilometer but ceilomenter is not installed in the # integrated gate, so specifying the services has not effect. # ceilometer-*: false

commit_message:
Reduce stestr concurrency to 1 for tempest jobs

The switch from testr to stestr introduced in Change-Id
Icf1f9eb4539666dffb6c9c1651670541523a9f9e missed setting concurrency
jobs to 1 for api and scenario tests, leading to intermittent gate
issues.

This patch also fixes coverage test that got broken in the
aforementioned Change-Id.

Change-Id: I052a9c3b376624f8e9e63faa98f4d09a93bdde4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/96/551796/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = stestr run '{posargs}' --concurrency 1 stestr slowestcommands = stestr run '{posargs}' --concurrency 1 stestr slowestcommands = stestr run '{posargs}' --concurrency 1 stestr slowest

commit_message:
Add nfs as a cinder backup driver option to CinderBackupBackend

Added nfs as an option to where CinderBackupBackend was hardcoded
as either ceph or swift. Also added some parameters for this
driver - CinderBackupNfsShare and CinderBackupNfsMountOptions

Change-Id: Id155e59703bf8b14da33ae54482b9d3bfcc4115e
Closes-Bug: #1744174

that we can do some attachment counting for multiattach
volumes being detached from instances on the same host.

Change-Id: If6e869b1c3516220b7deb0599d699caa2ed33889

commit_message:
Pass user context to virt driver when detaching volume

We need this in a later change to pull volume attachment
information from cinder for the volume being detached so
that we can do some attachment counting for multiattach
volumes being detached from instances on the same host.

(cherry-picked from commit d2941bfd165055348dd584b630d4e631ef05e328)

Change-Id: If6e869b1c3516220b7deb0599d699caa2ed33889
Related-Bug: #1752115
(cherry picked from commit e27b94287739207640b37ffd3e3a6b4176ef7cd3)

commit_message:
Virtual instance rescue with stable disk devices

This will provide the ability to indicate that the rescue disk image
should be attached as a transient disk device (ie USB stick), so that
existing storage attached to an instance doesn't change its device
address during rescue mode.

This version of the spec for Queens additionally describes changes to
the REST API requested during Newton.

Previously-approved: Mitaka, Newton

Change-Id: I6f9a7aa7e5306988230ae4c19045efc70c582244
Blueprint: virt-rescue-stable-disk-devices
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/06/510106/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Virtual instance rescue with stable disk devices ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/virt-rescue-stable-disk-devices This will provide the ability to indicate that the rescue disk image should be attached as a transient disk device (ie USB stick), so that existing storage attached to an instance doesn't change its device address during rescue mode. Problem description =================== When an instance is booted normally there are a number of possible disks that will be attached to the instance - An ephemeral/persistent root disk - Zero or more ephemeral non-root disks - Zero or more persistent non-root cinder volumes - An optional swap disk - An optional config drive disk When the instance is booted in rescue mode though, this storage setup changes significantly, and differently depending on virt drivers. In the libvirt driver, the rescue instance gets - A rescue root disk - The original root disk - An optional config drive disk There are multiple problems with this. First of all several of the disks are missing entirely, eg the ephemeral non-root disks, all cinder volumes and the swap disk. This missing storage limits the scope of work the admin can do in rescue mode. The rescue root disk is put on a device that previously held the real root disk. ie the rescue root is /dev/vda and the real root image is now shifted to a different device /dev/vdb. Although a well designed OS setup should not rely on the root device appearing at a fixed device name, some OS none the less do depend on this. Moving the root disk during rescue mode can thus introduce problems of its own, and in fact contribute to mistakes in rescue mode. eg it may confuse the admin into setting up their fstab to refer to /dev/vdb, when the root disk will go back to /dev/vda after rescue mode is finished. This change in disk presence during rescue mode is very different to what happens to disks on a baremetal machine when booted from rescue media. This means that admin knowledge from working in a bare metal world needs to be re-learnt for OpenStack rescue mode, which adds an undesirable learning burden for the admin. When disks change what address they appear at, this can cause upset licensing checks of some guests OS too. For example, if hardware devices change their address too frequently, Windows may decide to ask for license re-activation. This is again an undesirable thing for admins in general. Use Cases ---------- When the tenant user boots a VM in rescue mode they expect the existing storage device configuration to be identical to that seen when running in normal mode, but with an extra transient disk hotplugged to represent the rescue media. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== The compute manager code will be changed such that when rescue is performed the full block device mapping will be present. This will allow instances to be configured with the full set of cinder volumes that would appear during normal boot. The REST API will be updated such that: * The user knows whether stable rescue is requested or not. * The rescue behaviour will be as requested, or the request will fail. * Where possible the request will fail synchronously with no action taken if stable rescue is not supported. * Where not possible the request will fail asyncrhonously, but the instance will not be placed into an ERROR state if the only reason for the failure was that stable rescue is not supported. The latter is a wart. The api service knows whether the compute host is new enough to support stable rescue, but it doesn't know without making an additional rpc call whether the compute host is using a driver which also supports stable rescue. This means we can still fail asynchronously when requesting an unsupported stable rescue. We don't place the instance into an ERROR state as no recovery is required. Fixing this would require exposing the compute host's driver capabilities to the api service which I don't propose doing, at least initially. To implement this behaviour, we will bump the microversion of the REST api without adding any new parameters. Requesting the new microversion is explicitly requesting the stable rescue behaviour. Additionally, two new image properties will be defined to indicate that an image is a stable rescue image, and how it is to be used: - hw_rescue_bus=virtio|ide|usb|scsi - hw_rescue_device=disk|floppy|cdrom Together, these 2 changes form the user-facing API. If a user requests a rescue using the new microversion and specifies a rescue image with either 'hw_rescue_bus' or 'hw_rescue_device', the request is for stable rescue. If the request uses an older microversion, or the rescue image does not have either of these properties, we will use the old behaviour. If either of these 2 properties are omitted, they will use driver-specific defaults. For the libvirt driver, this means the default bus would match the hw_disk_bus, or the device type would be "disk". Internally, we will also bump the RPC version of the compute host, and add a 'stable' argument to ComputeManager.rescue_instance(). This will indicate to the api service that the compute host has been upgraded to a version which also supports stable rescue, which will allow it to fail the request synchronously. However, as noted above this isn't sufficient to ensure support by the compute host, so the request may still fail asynchronously. The recommended setup would be to tag the rescue image in glance with hw_rescue_bus=usb, which would indicate to the virt driver that it should attach a USB mass storage device to the guest containing the rescue image. For hypervisors which don't support this, an alternative would be to tag the rescue image with hw_rescue_bus=ide and hw_rescue_device=cdrom to cause a new CDROM device to be exposed with the rescue media. The libvirt driver will be changed so that when booting in rescue mode, all the cinder volumes, local ephemeral non-root disks and swap disks are present in rescue mode. The rescue root device will be added as the *last* device in the configuration, but will be marked as bootable for the BIOS, so it takes priority over the existing root device. This relies on KVM/QEMU supporting the "bootindex" parameter, which all supported versions do. This new rescue mode would not be supported by Xen, nor LXC. Other virt driver maintainers may wish to also implement this blueprint, so approval should be considered to give blessing to all virt drivers. If other virt driver maintainers wish to commit to doing this in Newton the list of assignees will be updated Alternatives ------------ Do nothing is always an option, but the current setup has a number of undesirable characteristics described earlier. An alternative might be to simply hardcode a different approach. eg when using KVM simply always use a USB mass storage device as the rescue media. This is certainly a viable option, and if it were not for the sake of maintaining backwards compatibility with earlier versions of OpenStack, it might even be the preferred approach. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- This change will define a new microversion, but will otherwise not change the REST API. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The tenant user will gain the ability to set a new image meta property against rescue disk images which will indicate the type of disk bus and device to use when rescuing instances. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- If the admin pre-populates any rescue disk images, they may wish to set the disk bus and device type to override the historic default behaviour. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mbooth Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Add a microversion for stable rescue. Extend the compute manager rescue code to handle the full block device mapping including cinder volume attachment. Extend the ImageMetaProps object to add the two new properties described. Extend the nova libvirt driver to setup all disks when running in rescue mode. Extend the nova libvirt driver to honour the new image meta properties in rescue mode disk config Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= A new tempest test can be used to validate correct operation of the new code. Documentation Impact ==================== The new image properties should be documented, and any information about rescue mode should be updated to explain how disks appear. References ========== None

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-13 02:54:42.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/install/configure-ipmi.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/013992bf6668d81e7a5649a313f7475907a644b7', 'message': "Update config option for collecting sensor data

This patch updates the notification driver option for collecting sensor
data because [DEFAULT]/notification_driver is deprecated and
'messaging' driver should only be used in cases where there are existing
consumers deployed which do not support the 2.0 message format.

Change-Id: Ia6c55149e5cb12d1201742f7008047e35570b410
"}]
commit_message:
Update config option for collecting sensor data

This patch updates the notification driver option for collecting sensor
data because [DEFAULT]/notification_driver is deprecated and
'messaging' driver should only be used in cases where there are existing
consumers deployed which do not support the 2.0 message format.

Change-Id: Ia6c55149e5cb12d1201742f7008047e35570b410
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/49/552249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

This patch makes it possible to build the Virtualbox-compatible OVA
archive withouth using vagrant, virtualbox, or vmware-specific tools.

Currently the created ova archive can be imported on VirtualBox and
VMWare Player, the disk image itself can be used with libvirt
(qemu-kvm). It contains all the drivers that enables using it
as a desktop system with shared clipboard, auto-resizing display, etc.

Since the diskimage-builder method installs in chroot, there is no way
to pre-install devstack by running stack.sh. The image makes a best
effort including all the deb and pip packages to make the first run of
stack.sh as short as possible.

Change-Id: Ie1f6e44db7e0af8d072cfdf16ace1ba3f749c246

(qemu-kvm). It contains all the drivers that enables using it
as a desktop system with shared clipboard, auto-resizing display, etc.

Since the diskimage-builder method installs in chroot, there is no way
to pre-install devstack by running stack.sh. The image makes a best
effort including all the deb and pip packages to make the first run of
stack.sh as short as possible.

Change-Id: Ie1f6e44db7e0af8d072cfdf16ace1ba3f749c246

commit_message:
Moving to diskimage-builder

This patch makes it possible to build the Virtualbox-compatible OVA
archive withouth using vagrant, virtualbox, or vmware-specific tools.

Currently the created ova archive can be imported on VirtualBox and
VMWare Player, the disk image itself can be used with libvirt
(qemu-kvm). It contains all the drivers that enables using it
as a desktop system with shared clipboard, auto-resizing display, etc.

Since the diskimage-builder method installs in chroot, there is no way
to pre-install devstack by running stack.sh. The image makes a best
effort including all the deb and pip packages to make the first run of
stack.sh as short as possible.

Change-Id: Ie1f6e44db7e0af8d072cfdf16ace1ba3f749c246

commit_message:
[CVE-2018-1000115] memcached: restrict to TCP & localhost

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2018-1000115

Restrict Memcached to only work on TCP and localhost.
The restriction is made at the application and firewall levels.
It will prevent DDoS amplification attacks using memcached.

Change-Id: I8072cc842291d133fde9fdfe9e8ad432623a8ef2
Related-Bug: #1754607
(cherry picked from commit 74fc85c507fc298828797c51255cee059a9684fc)

commit_message:
Implements validate_rescue() for IRMCVirtualMediaBoot

This commit implements validate_rescue() for 'irmc-virtual-media'
boot interface of 'irmc' hardware type.

With this it enables 'agent' rescue interface for 'irmc' hardware
type when corresponding boot interface being used is
'irmc-virtual-media'. Support already exists for the 'agent'
rescue interface with 'irmc-pxe' boot interface.

Also fix a bug in _remove_share_file() causing files
not to be removed correctly.

Change-Id: Ib602b2705b8fa4f7161b9f97857ec6546f5e9b19
Closes-Bug: #1747842
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/83/543883/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Only " "required if rescue mode is being used and ironic " "is managing booting the rescue ramdisk.") } def _parse_driver_info(node, mode='deploy'): :param mode: Label indicating a deploy or rescue operation being carried out on the node. Supported values are 'deploy' and 'rescue'. Defaults to 'deploy'. if mode == 'deploy': image_iso = d_info.get('irmc_deploy_iso') deploy_info['irmc_deploy_iso'] = image_iso else: image_iso = d_info.get('irmc_rescue_iso') deploy_info['irmc_rescue_iso'] = image_iso error_msg = (_("Error validating iRMC virtual media for %s. Some " "parameters were missing in node's driver_info") % mode) if service_utils.is_image_href_ordinary_file_name(image_iso): image_iso_file = os.path.join(CONF.irmc.remote_image_share_root, image_iso) if not os.path.isfile(image_iso_file): msg = (_("%(mode)s ISO file, %(iso_file)s, " {'mode': mode.capitalize(), 'iso_file': image_iso_file, 'node': node.uuid})def _setup_vmedia(task, mode, ramdisk_options): This method attaches the deploy or rescue ISO as virtual media, prepares the arguments for ramdisk in virtual media floppy. :param mode: Label indicating a deploy or rescue operation being carried out on the node. Supported values are 'deploy' and 'rescue'. if mode == 'rescue': iso = task.node.driver_info['irmc_rescue_iso'] else: iso = task.node.driver_info['irmc_deploy_iso'] if service_utils.is_image_href_ordinary_file_name(iso): iso_file = iso else: iso_file = _get_iso_name(task.node, label=mode) iso_fullpathname = os.path.join( CONF.irmc.remote_image_share_root, iso_file) images.fetch(task.context, iso, iso_fullpathname) _setup_vmedia_for_boot(task, iso_file, ramdisk_options)def _get_iso_name(node, label): """Returns the ISO file name for a given node. :param label: a string used as a base name for the ISO file. return "%s-%s.iso" % (label, node.uuid) boot_iso_filename = _get_iso_name(task.node, label='boot') deploy_iso_filename = _get_iso_name(task.node, label='deploy') boot_iso_filename = _get_iso_name(task.node, label='boot') _remove_share_file(_get_iso_name(node, label='deploy')) # TODO(tiendc): COMMON_PROPERTIES should also include rescue # related properties (RESCUE_PROPERTIES). We can add them in Rocky, # when classic drivers get removed. """Prepares the deploy or rescue ramdisk using virtual media. Prepares the options for the deploy or rescue ramdisk, sets the node to boot from virtual media cdrom. :param ramdisk_params: the options to be passed to the ramdisk. # aside from deployment, clean and rescue, such as conductor takeover, # we should treat this as a no-op and move on otherwise we would # modify the state of the node due to virtual media operations. if task.node.provision_state not in (states.DEPLOYING, states.CLEANING, states.RESCUING): if task.node.provision_state == states.RESCUING: mode = 'rescue' else: mode = 'deploy' _setup_vmedia(task, mode, ramdisk_params) deploy or rescue ramdisk. _remove_share_file(_get_iso_name(task.node, label='boot')) @METRICS.timer('IRMCVirtualMediaBoot.validate_rescue') def validate_rescue(self, task): """Validate that the node has required properties for rescue. :param task: a TaskManager instance with the node being checked :raises: MissingParameterValue if node is missing one or more required parameters :raises: InvalidParameterValue, if any of the parameters have invalid value. """ _parse_driver_info(task.node, mode='rescue')

Some parameters" " were missing in node's driver_info") if service_utils.is_image_href_ordinary_file_name( deploy_info['irmc_deploy_iso']): deploy_iso = os.path.join(CONF.irmc.remote_image_share_root, deploy_info['irmc_deploy_iso']) if not os.path.isfile(deploy_iso): msg = (_("Deploy ISO file, %(deploy_iso)s, " {'deploy_iso': deploy_iso, 'node': node.uuid})def _setup_deploy_iso(task, ramdisk_options): This method attaches the given deploy ISO as virtual media, prepares the arguments for ramdisk in virtual media floppy. d_info = task.node.driver_info deploy_iso_href = d_info['irmc_deploy_iso'] if service_utils.is_image_href_ordinary_file_name(deploy_iso_href): deploy_iso_file = deploy_iso_href else: deploy_iso_file = _get_deploy_iso_name(task.node) deploy_iso_fullpathname = os.path.join( CONF.irmc.remote_image_share_root, deploy_iso_file) images.fetch(task.context, deploy_iso_href, deploy_iso_fullpathname) _setup_vmedia_for_boot(task, deploy_iso_file, ramdisk_options)def _get_deploy_iso_name(node): """Returns the deploy ISO file name for a given node. return "deploy-%s.iso" % node.uuid def _get_boot_iso_name(node): """Returns the boot ISO file name for a given node. :param node: the node for which ISO file name is to be provided. """ return "boot-%s.iso" % node.uuid boot_iso_filename = _get_boot_iso_name(task.node) deploy_iso_filename = _get_deploy_iso_name(task.node) boot_iso_filename = _get_boot_iso_name(task.node) _remove_share_file(_get_deploy_iso_name(node)) """Prepares the deploy ramdisk using virtual media. Prepares the options for the deployment ramdisk, sets the node to boot from virtual media cdrom. :param ramdisk_params: the options to be passed to the deploy ramdisk. # aside from deployment and clean, such as conductor takeover, we # should treat this as a no-op and move on otherwise we would modify # the state of the node due to virtual media operations. if (task.node.provision_state != states.DEPLOYING and task.node.provision_state != states.CLEANING): _setup_deploy_iso(task, ramdisk_params) deploy ramdisk. _remove_share_file(_get_boot_iso_name(task.node))

commit_message:
Add LXC swap metric collector and fix lxc bug

LXC plugin throw up a exception when try collect cpu metrics. This
patch fix it (tests are passing) and add swap collector.

Change-Id: I3b12ac6ce199006bc1e024d2b2626657519e4f0b
Story: 2001563
Task: 6507

commit_message:
Fix telegraf output for influxdb

Kolla add multiple url in one outputs.influxdb.
This configuration is when influxdb is in cluster mode.
We need to write one conf by influxdb server.

Change-Id: I1c788b3c8400e74d50cace5a334311408989c5e1

commit_message:
Pass user context to virt driver when detaching volume

We need this in a later change to pull volume attachment
information from cinder for the volume being detached so
that we can do some attachment counting for multiattach
volumes being detached from instances on the same host.

(cherry-picked from commit d2941bfd165055348dd584b630d4e631ef05e328)

Change-Id: If6e869b1c3516220b7deb0599d699caa2ed33889
Related-Bug: #1752115

subject: Flush console log file before retrieving content
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-05 16:49:24.000000000', 'files': ['compute_hyperv/nova/serialconsoleops.py', 'compute_hyperv/tests/unit/test_serialconsolehandler.py', 'compute_hyperv/nova/serialconsolehandler.py', 'compute_hyperv/tests/unit/test_serialconsoleops.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv/commit/eb2c7b20a3e1328c1f3f5569bb5956a8ec230e8b', 'message': "Flush console log file before retrieving content

Hyper-V exposes instance serial console ports through named pipes.
We're consuming those named pipes, logging the output to a file,
retrieving the content when the console output is requested.

The issue is that the log file used by os-win never gets flushed
(unless closed). For this reason, we're returning incomplete output.

This change ensures that we're flushing the log file before attempting
to read its content.

Closes-Bug: #1741494

Change-Id: Ic558b16b317e0b1478cc259327d1336f7589afe3
Depends-On: I4b5eb7579ac0c92e9c3630539b0c4d76f5b98c6d
"}]
commit_message:
Flush console log file before retrieving content

Hyper-V exposes instance serial console ports through named pipes.
We're consuming those named pipes, logging the output to a file,
retrieving the content when the console output is requested.

The issue is that the log file used by os-win never gets flushed
(unless closed). For this reason, we're returning incomplete output.

This change ensures that we're flushing the log file before attempting
to read its content.

Closes-Bug: #1741494

Change-Id: Ic558b16b317e0b1478cc259327d1336f7589afe3
Depends-On: I4b5eb7579ac0c92e9c3630539b0c4d76f5b98c6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv refs/changes/26/531426/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
use is_extension_supported from neutron-lib

The is_extension_supported function now lives in neutron-lib. This patch
removes the function from neutron and uses lib's version instead.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: Iccb72e00f85043b3dff0299df7eb1279655e313e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/14/541914/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron_lib.api import extensions if extensions.is_extension_supported( self, constants.L3_HA_MODE_EXT_ALIAS):
deleted_lines: from neutron.common import utils as n_utils if n_utils.is_extension_supported(self, constants.L3_HA_MODE_EXT_ALIAS):

subject: Introduce keystoneauth adapters for clients
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-31 19:08:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/99a6a0e72cc86f57e8d7588c747711d08fe76ea0', 'message': "Improve endpoint_type handling

since [0] DevStack has simplified its keystone catalog by only
registering public endpoints for services, but ironic defaults to
'internal' API endpoints when discovering those from keystone catalog.

Although ironic was not broken yet due to explicitly setting the API urls
for various services in our config, we should move to discovery from
catalog eventually.
To support this, add 'endpoint_type' config options
for those services that might already use it (currently neutron and
service_catalog config sections, but others will follow).

Also, follow suit with DevStack by registering only a public ironic API
endpoint in our devstack plugin.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433272

Change-Id: I1283ef3b4d736ac089df0cc74a5850a93b24b6ab
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-06 14:04:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/c063cb791466f6bda83d8d0a87a88b95a3c5104e', 'message': "Improve endpoint_type handling

since [0] DevStack has simplified its keystone catalog by only
registering public endpoints for services, but ironic defaults to
'internal' API endpoints when discovering those from keystone catalog.

Although ironic was not broken yet due to explicitly setting the API urls
for various services in our config, we should move to discovery from
catalog eventually.
To support this, register keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter options to all
config sections for service clients auth.
Among others it exports 'interface' option, that can be set to 'public'
(default in keystoneauth1 and clients) or 'internal'.

Those service clients that need that right away have been changed to used it
(neutron and service_catalog).
Some options in those config sections have been deprecated as well,
as was [keystone]region_name option (and effectively the whole
[keystone] config section).

Also, follow suit with DevStack by registering only a public ironic API
endpoint in our devstack plugin.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433272

Change-Id: I1283ef3b4d736ac089df0cc74a5850a93b24b6ab

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2017-06-07 10:22:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/f29cc6d70effd84c94e376cf4765e6e55242aa98', 'message': "Improve endpoint interface handling

since [0] DevStack has simplified its keystone catalog by only
registering public endpoints for services, but ironic defaults to
'internal' API endpoints when discovering those from keystone catalog.

Although ironic was not broken yet due to explicitly or implicitly setting
the API urls for all services in our config, we should move to discovery from
catalog eventually.

To support this, register keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter options to all
config sections for service clients auth.
Among others it exports `interface` option, that can be set to 'public'
(default in keystoneauth1 and clients) or 'internal'.
Other exported options are `service_type`, `service_name`, `region_name`
and `endpoint_override`.
The latter will eventually be used by all clients to specify a specific
endpoint to use (for example in noauth mode).

Effectively this patch starts to move all clients code to load client
configuration from config for all of auth, session and adapter.

Those service clients that need that right away have been changed to used it
(neutron and service_catalog).
Some options in those config sections have been deprecated as well
(those which are covered by session and adapter options)
as was [keystone]region_name option (and effectively the whole
[keystone] config section).

Also, follow suit with DevStack by registering only a public ironic API
endpoint in our devstack plugin.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433272

Change-Id: I1283ef3b4d736ac089df0cc74a5850a93b24b6ab

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2017-06-21 15:01:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/69435b80081b1d3961526abb3bbd0b91ed3bb85d', 'message': "Introcude keystoneauth adapters for clients

since [0] DevStack has simplified its keystone catalog by only
registering public endpoints for services, but ironic defaults to
'internal' API endpoints when discovering those from keystone catalog.

Although ironic was not broken yet due to explicitly or implicitly setting
the API urls for all services in our config, we should move to discovery from
catalog eventually.

To support this, register keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter options to all
config sections for service clients auth.
Among others it exports `interface` option, that can be set to 'public'
(default in keystoneauth1 and clients) or 'internal'.
Other exported options are `service_type`, `service_name`, `region_name`
and `endpoint_override`.
The latter will eventually be used by all clients to specify a specific
endpoint to use (for example in noauth mode).

Effectively this patch starts to move all clients code to load client
configuration from config for all of auth, session and adapter.
The first to move is [service_catalog] section, with [conductor]api_url
option being deprecated in favor of [service_catalog]endpoint_override.
More patches moving other clients to consume these new options and
deprecate some other options will follow.

Also, follow suit with DevStack by registering only a public ironic API
endpoint in our devstack plugin.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433272

"}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2017-06-22 12:27:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/2b2f9a813a0a3b3f8c0ae3e2a259e55025ec9787', 'message': "Introduce keystoneauth adapters for clients

since [0] DevStack has simplified its keystone catalog by only
registering public endpoints for services, but ironic defaults to
'internal' API endpoints when discovering those from keystone catalog.

Currently ironic explicitly or implicitly sets the API urls for most services
in the config. This is quite fragule and we should move to discovery from
catalog eventually.

To support this, register keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter options to all
config sections for service clients auth.
Among others it exports `interface` option (default of None is usually
treated by clients as 'public').
Other exported options are `service_type`, `service_name`, `region_name`
and `endpoint_override`.
The latter will eventually be used by all clients to specify a specific
endpoint to use (for example in noauth mode).

Effectively this patch starts to move all clients code to load client
configuration from config for all of auth, session and adapter.
The first to move is [service_catalog] section, with [conductor]api_url
option being deprecated in favor of [service_catalog]endpoint_override.
More patches moving other clients to consume these new options and
deprecate some other options will follow.
This patch also deprecates [keystone]region_name option in favor of
per-service `region_name` option in config sections for each service.

The config sample is updated with only those options that might actually
be used already, others will be added as their handling is enabled in
subsequent patches.

Also, follow suit with DevStack by registering only a public ironic API
endpoint in our devstack plugin.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433272

Change-Id: I1283ef3b4d736ac089df0cc74a5850a93b24b6ab
Partial-Bug: #1699547
Partial-Bug: #1699542

commit_message:
Introduce keystoneauth adapters for clients

Currently ironic explicitly or implicitly sets the API urls
for most services in the config.
This is quite fragile and we should move to discovery from
the keystone catalog eventually.

To support this, this patch registers `keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter`
options to all config sections for service clients auth.
Among others it exports `interfaces` option that we set to
['internal', 'public'] by default.
Other exported options are `service_type`, `service_name`, `region_name`
and `endpoint_override`.
The latter will eventually be used by all clients to specify a specific
endpoint to use (for example in noauth mode).

Effectively this patch starts to move all clients code to load client
configuration from config for all of auth, session and adapter.

The first to move is [service_catalog] section, with [conductor]api_url
option being deprecated in favor of [service_catalog]endpoint_override.
A sane default of 'service_type' = 'baremetal' is set for this config
section as well.

More patches moving other clients to consume these new options and
deprecate some other options will follow.

Change-Id: I1283ef3b4d736ac089df0cc74a5850a93b24b6ab
Partial-Bug: #1699547
Related-Bug: #1699542

subject: Add reno for RBAC and client incompatibility
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-13 13:17:20.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/RBAC-and-client-incompatibility-fdfeab326dfda3bf.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/23bc66790554b4c9e89e738203e49cb90d37e416', 'message': 'Add reno for RBAC and client incompatibility

Magnumclients older than 2.9.0 (<=2.80) can not create
certificates for RBAC enabled clients. Affects only
k8s_fedora_atomic. This patch adds the relevant reno.

Change-Id: Idab265a41b1bf2da83d29eb942b9f4568ee4cf99
'}]
commit_message:
Add reno for RBAC and client incompatibility

Magnumclients older than 2.9.0 (<=2.80) can not create
certificates for RBAC enabled clients. Affects only
k8s_fedora_atomic. This patch adds the relevant reno.

Change-Id: Idab265a41b1bf2da83d29eb942b9f4568ee4cf99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/10/552510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | k8s_fedora_atomic clusters are deployed with RBAC support. Along with RBAC Node authorization is added so the appropriate certificates are generated. upgrade: - | Using the queens (>=2.9.0) python-magnumclient, when a user executes openstack coe cluster config, the client certificate has admin as Common Name (CN) and system:masters for Organization which are required for authorization with RBAC enabled clusters. This change in the client is backwards compatible, so old clusters (without RBAC enabled) can be reached with certificates generated by the new client. However, old magnum clients will generate certificates that will not be able to contact RBAC enabled clusters. This issue affects only k8s_fedora_atomic clusters and clients <=2.8.0, note that 2.8.0 is still a queens release but only 2.9.0 includes the relevant patch. Finally, users can always generate and sign the certificates using this [0] procedure even with old clients since only the cluster config command is affected. [0] https://docs.openstack.org/magnum/latest/user/index.html#interfacing-with-a-secure-cluster

commit_message:
Rename dummy_shard_range to own_shard_range

Also fix comments, remove unused 'part' arg and
tighten up test for acceptor being same as
own_shard_range.

Related-Change: I43cb6285537a24163bfe1245fe15fe1f1393294b

Change-Id: Ie4089e7fdc1645e672b79c35fe6e490f2645d683
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/72/552472/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._find_shrinks(broker) def _find_shrinks(self, broker): # this should only execute on root containers that have sharded; the # goal is to find small shard containers that could be retired by # merging with a neighbour. own_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range() # TODO: in future own_shard_range will exist and have sharded state # but for now this could be first time own_shard_range is touched # and so we need to make it active in order to satisfy the # conditions for an acceptor own_shard_range.state = ShardRange.ACTIVE shard_ranges.append(own_shard_range) if acceptor is not own_shard_range: # prevent it treating objects cleaved from the donor
deleted_lines: self._find_shrinks(broker, part) def _find_shrinks(self, broker, part): # this should only execute on root containers; the goal is to find # small shard containers that could be retired by merging with a # neighbour. dummy_shard_range = None # Note: currently this dummy shard range is not persisted in root # shard_ranges table; the donor shard does not include it when # updating the root after cleaving itself. dummy_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range() dummy_shard_range.state = ShardRange.ACTIVE shard_ranges.append(dummy_shard_range) if acceptor != dummy_shard_range: # prevent it treating object updates redirected from the donor

commit_message:
Transform servergroup.addmember notification

The servergroup.addmember notification has been transformed
to the versioned notification framework.

Change-Id: I5291e453ba06f0f26c4928e4f7482c40e725a781
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-rocky
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/541101/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @rpc.if_notifications_enabled def notify_about_server_group_add_member(context, group_id): group = objects.InstanceGroup.get_by_uuid(context, group_id) payload = sg_notification.ServerGroupPayload(group) notification = sg_notification.ServerGroupNotification( priority=fields.NotificationPriority.INFO, publisher=notification_base.NotificationPublisher( host=CONF.host, source=fields.NotificationSource.API), event_type=notification_base.EventType( object='server_group', action=fields.NotificationAction.ADD_MEMBER), payload=payload) notification.emit(context)

commit_message:
Add reno for RBAC and client incompatibility

Magnumclients older than 2.9.0 (<=2.80) can not create
certificates for RBAC enabled clients. Affects only
k8s_fedora_atomic. This patch adds the relevant reno.

Change-Id: Idab265a41b1bf2da83d29eb942b9f4568ee4cf99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/26/550826/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | k8s_fedora_atomic clusters are deployed with RBAC support. Along with RBAC Node authorization is added so the appropriate certificates are generated. upgrade: - | Using the queens (>=2.9.0) python-magnumclient, when a user executes openstack coe cluster config, the client certificate has admin as Common Name (CN) and system:masters for Organization which are required for authorization with RBAC enabled clusters. This change in the client is backwards compatible, so old clusters (without RBAC enabled) can be reached with certificates generated by the new client. However, old magnum clients will generate certificates that will not be able to contact RBAC enabled clusters. This issue affects only k8s_fedora_atomic clusters and clients <=2.8.0, note that 2.8.0 is still a queens release but only 2.9.0 includes the relevant patch. Finally, users can always generate and sign the certificates using this [0] procedure even with old clients since only the cluster config command is affected. [0] https://docs.openstack.org/magnum/latest/user/index.html#interfacing-with-a-secure-cluster

commit_message:
Fix N358 hacking check

Two different hacking checks were reporting N357. This changes the
second to report N358 (as comments indicate it was meant to) and
fixes the unit tests to check this.

Change-Id: I35614c61d3a01e31cbcaa193cf7a04c58bdcb310

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(1, len(list(checks.return_followed_by_space( "return(42)")))) self.assertEqual(1, len(list(checks.return_followed_by_space( "return(' some string ')")))) self.assertEqual(0, len(list(checks.return_followed_by_space( "return 42")))) self.assertEqual(0, len(list(checks.return_followed_by_space( "return ' some string '")))) self.assertEqual(0, len(list(checks.return_followed_by_space( "return (int('40') + 2)"))))

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ib4aa233c76512e8e0d3dc3dd519160114f9bfa25

commit_message:
Add file type check to upload-swift-artifacts

deploy-artifacts supports only 'RPM' and 'gzip compressed data' [1]
while upload-swift-artifacts will allow the uploading
of any file. deploy-artifacts will fail if an unsupported file
type is downloaded resutling in a stack deploy failure.

This update add a check_file function which will validate the
file type of each file before it is uploaded. The script will
exit with a failure if an unsupported file is attempted.

Change-Id: I8c46110fa2779b818bc5b7882788f5d8739c1d2a
1: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/puppet/deploy-artifacts.sh#L12-L23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/12/544412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function check_file { FILE=$1 supported_files=(" RPM " "gzip compressed data") array_length=${#supported_files[@]} test_type=`file $FILE` i=0 matched=0 while [ $i -ne $array_length -a $matched -eq 0 ] do if [[ "$test_type" =~ ${supported_files[$i]} ]] then matched=1 fi i=$((i+1)) done if [ $matched -eq 0 ] then echo "Not a supported file type: $FILE" exit 1 fi } check_file "$FILE"

commit_message:
Pin puppet-systemd

puppet-systemd recently added a breaking change to pull the module
parameter defaults via hiera. This only works in puppet >= 4.10.0 which
we are not using. So we need to pin to an earlier commit since we're
usign 4.8.x.

Change-Id: I11c8372eb20d9ff67bcc91897118061d7f193a54
Closes-Bug: #1755211
(cherry picked from commit bd5599ca59b168ce4785991c4165fa4196b8d78a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/67/552167/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pin puppet-systemd

puppet-systemd recently added a breaking change to pull the module
parameter defaults via hiera. This only works in puppet >= 4.10.0 which
we are not using. So we need to pin to an earlier commit since we're
usign 4.8.x.

Change-Id: I11c8372eb20d9ff67bcc91897118061d7f193a54
Closes-Bug: #1755211
(cherry picked from commit 8777c2911a2de899bf0cb58487973962cf3ebcee)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/68/552168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pin puppet-systemd

puppet-systemd recently added a breaking change to pull the module
parameter defaults via hiera. This only works in puppet >= 4.10.0 which
we are not using. So we need to pin to an earlier commit since we're
usign 4.8.x.

Change-Id: I11c8372eb20d9ff67bcc91897118061d7f193a54
Closes-Bug: #1755211
(cherry picked from commit bd5599ca59b168ce4785991c4165fa4196b8d78a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/65/552165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added t-h-t for tempest container

It adds a fake tempest service in order to make tempest
container available on undercloud.

Change-Id: If580292572ee5a11a41f68752a6ffe8a99f066e7

commit_message:
Add prefixlen to subnet api-ref for create actions

Prefixlen is used in subnet creation when allocating a subnet
from a subnet pool.

Change-Id: I251944ca15434ed9b17deb829cca985cd94a0bd1
Closes-bug: #1754062
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/88/550588/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Save rc from stack.sh in run-devstack role

Avoid overriding the failure state of stack.sh by the trailing echo
command.

Change-Id: I74820709edc98f67ff1a0c620ce5db3a3571b7f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/41/552041/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
